ticket.title: Weird classes namespace whith cache_classes = false
ticket.original-body:
Hi,
I've observed a weird behavior of loading classes with namespace. I have a class that is not in a module:
class RedactionControllers < ActionController::Base end
I can access it normally:
Loading development environment (Rails 3.0.0) ruby-1.9.2-p0 > RedactionController => RedactionController
But I should not be able to access it in a namespace:
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > Redaction::RedactionController => RedactionController
But, if I change `config.cache_classes` from `false` to `true` (in my development environment), I have the expected behavior:
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > Redaction::RedactionController NameError: uninitialized constant Redaction::RedactionController
This bug has some consequences. In my case, I have this route:
namespace :redaction do root :to => "redaction#index" end
Everything works well in development (with `config.cache_classes = false`), but it explodes in production (with `config.cache_classes = true`):
Routing Error uninitialized constant Redaction::RedactionController
We should fix this difference between development and production to avoid that developers discover some bugs on the production.

class RedactionControllers < ActionController::Base end

ruby-1.9.2-p0 > Redaction::RedactionController NameError: uninitialized constant Redaction::RedactionController
This bug has some consequences. In my case, I have this route:
namespace :redaction do root :to => "redaction#index" end
Everything works well in development (with `config.cache_classes = false`), but it explodes in production (with `config.cache_classes = true`):

We should fix this difference between development and production to avoid that developers discover some bugs on the production.
ticket.original-body-html:
Hi,

I've observed a weird behavior of loading classes with namespace. I have a class that is not in a module:

class RedactionControllers < ActionController::Base
end

I can access it normally:

Loading development environment (Rails 3.0.0)
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > RedactionController 
 => RedactionController

But I should not be able to access it in a namespace:

ruby-1.9.2-p0 > Redaction::RedactionController
 => RedactionController

But, if I change config.cache_classes from false to true (in my development environment), I have the expected behavior:

ruby-1.9.2-p0 > Redaction::RedactionController
NameError: uninitialized constant Redaction::RedactionController

This bug has some consequences. In my case, I have this route:

namespace :redaction do
  root :to => "redaction#index"
end

Everything works well in development (with config.cache_classes = false), but it explodes in production (with config.cache_classes = true):

Routing Error
uninitialized constant Redaction::RedactionController

We should fix this difference between development and production to avoid that developers discover some bugs on the production.

This bug has some consequences. In my case, I have this route:

Everything works well in development (with `config.cache_classes = false`), but it explodes in production (with `config.cache_classes = true`):

We should fix this difference between development and production to avoid that developers discover some bugs on the production.

version.body: For the record, this bug seems related to https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/5383-as-dependencies-resolver-broken-not-missing-constant-error

version.title: Weird classes namespace whith cache_classes = false
Weird classes namespace whith cache_classes = false

version.body:
In my example, Redaction is a module, and the bug is only if the nesting namesapce is a module (not a class). So i've updated my test case to reflect that.
I've tried to fix this bug, but I can't find how to differentiate `A::B` from `module A; B; end` in the autoloading stuff.
version.body-html:
In my example, Redaction is a module, and the bug is only if the nesting namesapce is a module (not a class). So i've updated my test case to reflect that.

I've tried to fix this bug, but I can't find how to differentiate A::B from module A; B; end in the autoloading stuff.
version.title: Weird classes namespace whith cache_classes = false

version.body:
The patch with the failing test case no longer seems to apply cleanly:
@@@ Applying: Failing test case for #5735 fatal: corrupt patch at line 23 Patch failed at 0001 Failing test case for #5735 When you have resolved this problem run "git am --resolved". If you would prefer to skip this patch, instead run "git am --skip". To restore the original branch and stop patching run "git am --abort". @@@
Could you please update it, and perhaps provide a fix if you figured it out?
version.body-html:
The patch with the failing test case no longer seems to apply cleanly:

Applying: Failing test case for #5735
fatal: corrupt patch at line 23
Patch failed at 0001 Failing test case for #5735
When you have resolved this problem run "git am --resolved".
If you would prefer to skip this patch, instead run "git am --skip".
To restore the original branch and stop patching run "git am --abort".

Could you please update it, and perhaps provide a fix if you figured it out?
version.title: Weird classes namespace whith cache_classes = false

version.body: I've updated the patch for the failing test case, but I didn't figure how to fix it without breaking others tests. Seems like it's a complex task, that needs a deep comprehension of loading of classes and modules.

This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.
Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
